MARIO SMALL: Thank you
all for the invitation.

Thanks to [? Ray ?] and
[? Maureen ?] for the wonderful
talks.

Obviously, I'm still
thinking about them.

I'd like to talk
about, what I did not

realize was going to
be so closely tied

to both of the talks,
which is [? her ?]

a particular kind of privileged
ally, which is the mentor.

I think everybody
here knows as well

as anyone that mentors are
essential for the ability

to people who are in populations
that are not typically

part of highly
powerful positions,

in not just the corporate world,
but in policy and academia,
cetera.

We all know that
mentors are essential.

And we all know
that most of us got

to where we are through
some form of mentorship.

Sometimes quiet mentorship,
behind the scenes,

as I've learned increasingly
as I've moved up myself.

And so I would like to
talk a little bit about

is the difficulties that can
come from this particular kind

of ally to be an
effective mentor, even
under the best of circumstances.
And you'll have to forgive me.

Not only am I an in an
extremely meditative state

after that talk,
but to top it off

I have a baby who's very
lovely, is my first.
And she-- lovely.
12-months.

And yesterday she had
a round of vaccines,
the kind that really hurt.
And so nobody slept last night.

So it's going to take
me a minute to wake up.
OK, mentoring.

Mentoring is useful for
a number of reasons.

As everybody here knows,
but it's worth remembering,

a good mentor provides
access through at least three
different ways.
One is information.

A good mentor tells you which
jobs to take and not take,

helps you avoid
pitfalls, and so on.

Helps you figure out
pathways to success for you,

that you may not have
realized, helping

you invest your time and energy
in the right kinds of things.

A second thing a mentor
provides is connections.

For mentors, effective
enough and powerful enough,

a mentor can
literally connect you

to people and organizations
that are important

for you to move, to know
as you move up, regardless

of your [? illness, ?]
or whether it's

in policy, in government,
in non-profits,
in corporate America, et cetera.

And the third thing
I mentor provides,

which I think should
not be forgotten

in this particular
context, is support.

A good mentor, and again I'm
talking about at the extremes,
is a confidant.

Not necessarily emotionally,
but frankly often emotionally.

A person who could
say, you know what?

What you're experiencing,
it's actually not that rare,

or here's how to deal with it,
or let me just listen to you
vent.

Because as we all know, moving
up is hard and stressful.

We also know that
mentoring often fails,

and it often fails for
also well known reasons.

A lack of commitment, literally
even in the best of cases.

And I'm talking both about
those formal mentoring programs
that we've all heard about.

I'm part of a couple of them
myself, where you're encouraged

to mentor people
because we know it's

good for young
people, et cetera.

Some of [? these ?] lack
of commitment, literally.

You don't provide the
information that you could

or [? write the ?] guidance at
the times that you could of.
You're just not aware.

Sometimes it's
just lack of power.

You yourself, even
though you're a saint,

you are not connected enough
to really help anybody,

to open the kinds of
doors required to move up
in certain kinds of contexts.

And the third is just the lack
of the basic trustworthiness

or skill required to be a
good listener, to really

be able to help people navigate
difficult circumstances.

And in fact, we just heard I
think really provocatively,

a context in which speaking
up can be quite difficult

without the right
kind of guidance.
So good mentors are committed.
They're powerful to some extent.

And they're skilled in the
sense that they can capture.

They understand the
person as a person

and can be essentially
a good confidant.

What I'd like to talk
about is the circumstances

in which even
outstanding mentors, who

are all of these
things, can nonetheless

fail for reasons that have less
to do with them as individuals

than with the mentor relation
and the institutions in which
the mentor relation is embedded.

In other words, a mentor
is a more powerful person

who's helping a less
powerful person move up.

In an institutional context,
where the possibility of

ambiguity of multiple times, can
actually undermine the relation
even in the best of cases.

And I'm going to give you a case
to make this concrete, in part

because we're at the
Harvard Business School

and [? cases ?] are the way
everybody does everything here.

That was a positive
comment just to be clear.

But before that,
I'd like to discuss

one particular
ambiguity that I think
is particularly important.

And again, thinking
about the fact

that a mentor relation is a
relation that is happening
in a particular context.

And I'd like to talk about,
and just briefly, introduce
the idea of reciprocity.

We think of mentors as
confidence in some senses,

so let's think about
the idea of reciprocity

in the particular sense
in which a confidant might
be a reciprocal relation.

So most relations
have of a reciprocity.

So for example, my wife and
I have a reciprocal relation

in the sense that if I
need to vent something--

vent about something
on a particular day,

I can expect that at
some time down the line
she's going to be able to--

she's going to feel a need,
and I have the obligation
to listen to her vent.

In other words, we have
an emotional reciprocity
that is relevant.
That reciprocity is useful.

There are other
kinds of relations

that also have a reciprocity,
but the reciprocity
is not emotional.

If I vented to my
therapist, I don't really

expect my therapist to then
vent back to me at a later time.

In fact, that
would be very weird

and exactly the opposite of
what I expect the therapist.

But what the therapist
expects is a check,

and that is in a
sense the reciprocity.

And you can say, well, there
are other kinds of therapists
like priests and rabbis.

Well, they also expect checks
in different ways or commitments
of other sorts.

But the idea is in
any kind of relation,

either the relationship is
emotional, reciprocal or not,

there's something you give as
a result of having received.

What I'd like to propose is
that in many mentor relations

there is what we can think
of as a reciprocal ambiguity,

a ambiguity about the
right form of reciprocating

and whether it has
happened that can undermine

even the best of mentors and
the relations-- an even the best
of circumstances.

And the way to think about
it, broadly, is this.

If I am an extraordinary
mentor to somebody and I've

helped and provide information,
and provide connections,

and listened to
this young person.

That person feels indebted
as in any relation.

How does that person know
that they've reciprocated?

I'm certainly not going
to ask that person

to listen to my problems,
to provide access

to information they don't have
or to products to connections
they don't have.

What is the nature
of the reciprocity?

What I'm going to argue
and show you in a case

is that the ambiguity
that can arise

as a result of that dynamic, can
actually undermine the mentor

relation in ways
that matter for how

we think about how an
ally, privileged ally,
can help or not help.

And as you'll see they can even
have consequences such that--

an [? I ?] have a
language to describe this,

those difficulties
can actually be

embodied in the
relation itself, which

is part of why I'm so surprised
in part of why it's reflective.
So I like to discuss the case.

And the case I'm one of this
cry of is the academic context.

And it's a mentor relation
in an economic context
for a couple of reasons.

One is obviously, the academic
context of a first real step
in many fields--
big stem as an obvious case.

But with respect to mentoring
both masters and [? QC ?]

programs across the
board, just closer

to the workplace than
they are to schooling.

The second reason I want to
talk about the economic context

is that I happen to be
leading, at the moment,

as in today and for the
next many months, a task

force of more than
40 people, here

at Harvard, that's trying to
address student mental health.

Improvement of health among
students, both undergraduate

but also graduate and
professional students.

Because it turns out
that mental health

problems have risen, not
just as a secular issue,

but even in the last three
years across the board,

and we're trying to figure
out a way of addressing this.

The third reason I want to
talk about an academic context

is because I just wrote
a book, in which I

talk about these issues
in an academic context,

and so I have a
case to give you.

I'd so I'd like if
you'd indulge me.

I'm going to read for you a
short passage from the book

to introduce a
case that may help

inform the discussion that
we're going to have in a minute.

In this particular case I want
to discuss a graduate student,

whom I call in the book,
[? Queenie. ?] And her advisor

[? Hanz, ?] whom
[? Queenie ?] feels very close

to because he's an
extremely effective mentor.

[? Queenie ?] has known
[? Hanz ?] for many years
in fact.

And for the particular issues
that worried [? Queenie, ?]

[? Hanz ?] had repeatedly found
himself to be an especially
informative and useful mentor.

[? "Queenie ?] was a social
science student who was smart

thoughtful driven and deeply
conflicted in whether she

should have enrolled in
her PDT program at all.

She had been an undergraduate
at the same university

[? Hillmount. ?] And
in her senior year,

and without knowing
exactly what she wanted,

she applied to four
graduate programs,
which she was an undergrad.

Not surprisingly, given that
she didn't know what she wanted,

she was accepted
at none of them.

Despondent, she left town,
moved in with her boyfriend,
and took a regular job.

Nonetheless, she kept in
touch with several faculty,

including her BA thesis advisor
who was [? Hanz. ?] Two years

later, and now more
intellectually and personally

mature [? Queenie, ?]
applied to programs again.

This time she was
accepted at two programs.

One was [? Hillmount ?]
and the other one

was a dream program that
was an exceptionally good
intellectual fit.

The program also offered
her a much larger grant

than [? Hillmount ?]
did, and it was
a top 5 program in the country.

In addition, contrary
to Hillmount,

it was located in the city where
[? Queenie ?] and her fiancee
now lived.

The choice seemed
completely obvious.

But [? Queenie ?]
was conflicted.

With little real
evidence, [? Queenie ?]

had concluded that her
success in the second round

of applications was to not
to her greater maturity,

but her advisors letters of
recommendation-- to the access

that the powerful
mentor had provided."

I'm quoting now,
as you can tell.

'They kind of pushed
for me hard' unquote.

She felt a deep
sense of obligation.

Had her advisors, I
asked, try to force

Quote, 'I mean, they told me it
was better for me to come here.

But [? Hanz ?]
never said like you

have to come to Hillmount
or anything like that.

But I just felt
indebted, and very loyal
and very appreciative' unquote.

"That sense of loyalty and
obligation may seem strange.

The fact that her advisor
wrote a strong letter

of recommendation is
not actually special.
In fact, it's part of his job.

And even if
[? Hanz ?] had somehow

written nicer things
that were warranted given

her record, which
I frankly doubt,

recommendation letters
today as we all know,

are an exercise in
hyperbole and exaggeration.

They are the narrative
version of great inflation.

I sometimes say
that some professors

seem to have the best student
they've taught in decades year
after year."

They must be living in

Each with its allocation of

Anyway, "In fact, the
advisors professional role

requires providing students
with many kinds of support,

including scholarly,
professional,
and personal advice."

I'm not telling you anything

"Advisors are confidence.

What [? Hanz ?] did
was par for the course.

However, the relation between
an advisor and a student
is distinct in two ways.

First, [? law ?] advisors as
mentors are required to support

students, they often,
as [? in Hanz ?] case,

have a choice of which
students to support.

Time is a zero sum resource
and advisors can only

invest in one student
at the expense
of time spent in another.
No mentor can mentor everybody.
Mentors have to choose.

Thus, this former support is
an investment which students

are expected to reciprocate,
even if this expectation is not
stated explicitly.

Second, although the student
is expected to reciprocate,

the proper form reciprocity
is not always clear.

An advisor-student
relation is a lot

like the relation between
the therapist and a patient

in that emotional
support typically

travels only in one direction,
at least in the healthy ones.

Advisors, like therapists,
do not vent their problems
to their students.
Again, at least the good ones.

But a patient knows
that in return

for the therapist support
she must write a check.

When a student receives
support from an advisor,

what exactly must she
do to reciprocate?
Do well in her classes?

Work hard try to compete her
time assignments on time?

While surely all of these
are probably some part of it,

how will a student know that
the debt, the emotional debt
has been repaid?

That this favor that this
wonderful mentor did for you,
you've now finally paid off?
The answer is simply unknown.

And this ambiguity, in fact, is
an important source of control
on the part of the advisor.

It is a form of power, as
Nietzsche would call it,

even if a benign advisor
decides not to exercise it.

One of the deepest
forms of obligation

is to know that one is indebted
while being sure exactly
how the debt must be repaid."

So that was [? Queenie's ?]
predicament.
And its effect was twofold.
First, that enrollment.

This was her first

'OK unquote, if she

So she went to
[? Hillmount. ?] Now,

six months into her

Quote 'And it's a very strange

"While many students
worry about their fit

with their programs--"
for those of you who

[? "Queenie's ?] consternation

It was a sense of

of what she was reminded every

and every day she awoke on a bed

Quote, 'I wake up in the morning

"I asked her to explain."
Quote.
'It is a huge regret of mine.
And I have to move past it.

But it just feels like
I gave up something

that I really wanted for
the sake of somebody else.

For some, you know, other
people I suppose to myself,

and that's what really

"The anguish was relentless."
Quote.

'I mean, I'm constantly
thinking about it.

There are few moments
where I don't feel it.

Even in the background,
a pain, a regret.

It's probably the most

"Earlier in the

had reported three people

We were asking people

and when they had

Her boyfriend, her longtime

I asked her, if she ever

This is, if you were

Who do you talk about it?

"She certainly had

which wasn't surprising.
She had talked to Marla.
But she also had [? Hanz." ?]

And if you think

[? Hanz, ?] if anybody

no [? Queenie, ?]

You could have gone

Quote, 'I don't know my

Hanz would know them.
They were all so close'

"And she knew she
could trust him.
And he was probably aware."

Quote, 'I mean,
I think he knows.

He knows I'm constantly
traveling out

of town to see my boyfriend, and
that this takes a toll on me'

"But there's a second way the
ambiguity of the predicament
affected her.

Though [? Hanz ?] was
perfect to talk to,
she explicitly avoided him."
And we're almost done.

Quote, 'I don't really
feel comfortable

at this stage talking to
him about wanting to leave'
"In fact--" Unquote.

"In fact, she never
broached the topic.

A year later, she finally
had realized that it probably

would have been OK to have
gone to the other program.

But she was still unclear
whether talking about it now,

a year and a half later,
would violate expectations

about the proper
form of reciprocity.

Close relations, I argue,
are not immune from ambiguity

and neither are, even in
the best of intentions,
close advisor relations--
close mental relations.

For [? Queenie, ?]
the ambiguity paved

the way for a kind of
power and one in which

the student ultimately
regulated herself.

They were close
perhaps too close."

To wrap up, I'd like to
propose three things for us
to think about.

One is that power and
these kinds of relations
is inevitable.

A privileged ally, to use
the language in a sense,

and a mentor in this particular
sense, is more powerful.
It's unavoidable.

And so the question
is, how do we

manage that particular
situation in a world in which we

think and believe that mentors
are going to be important?

This is especially
the case, given

that today mentors for
women, for people of color

are very often not going to
be other women or other people
of color.

We simply don't
have the numbers.

It's just not going
to be the case.

It will not be the case that the
majority of students of color

who come through
this program are

going to have a
faculty of color,

or only faculty of
color as mentors

because there's just
not the numbers yet.

So there's something that
we had to take into account.

Second, ambiguity may
not be, but it often is.

Ambiguity both about
how to repay the debts

and second about knowing
when you're done.

When do you no longer
have to repay the debts

to your advisor, to your
mentor, to the person
to open doors for you.
It's unclear.

I like to think about what
are ways in which increasing

transparency might actually
help lower ambiguity for those
in the less powerful position.

And lastly, I'd like to
conclude with one thing.

Look, it's easy
for us, all adults,

all who've been through
some version of this process

to see the error in
her ways in retrospect.
But think about it this way.

Every time every single
person in this room

moves up in some way,
moves up in some ladder

to a new position, to a new
role, to a new organization,

to a new university we
seize becoming experts

in that lower rung in
the ladder we were,

and we become total
rookies in the new one.

It's not clear to me that
in those circumstances

there aren't equally
unknown norms.

Norms that are unwritten rules
or norms or expectations that,

because we've never been
there, are unknown to us.

That we, just like
[? Queenie, ?] might have fear
we're violating.

So I'd like us to
think of this, not

as an instance of a young person
who just needs to grow up,

but an instance of
any kind of person

entering a new context in
which, if you're moving up,
guess what?

You're starting from
being a rookie once again.
Thank you very much.
